drug.name: Rivastigmine
drug.description: Rivastigmine is a parasympathomimetic or cholinergic agent for the treatment of mild to moderate dementia of the Alzheimer's type. Rivastigmine is a cholinesterase inhibitor that inhibits both butyrylcholinesterase and acetylcholinesterase.

article.citation: Camps P, Munoz-Torrero D: Cholinergic drugs in pharmacotherapy of Alzheimer's disease. Mini Rev Med Chem. 2002 Feb;2(1):11-25.

Rosler M, Anand R, Cicin-Sain A, Gauthier S, Agid Y, Dal-Bianco P, Stahelin HB, Hartman R, Gharabawi M: Efficacy and safety of rivastigmine in patients with Alzheimer's disease: international randomised controlled trial. BMJ. 1999 Mar 6;318(7184):633-8.
Finkel SI: Effects of rivastigmine on behavioral and psychological symptoms of dementia in Alzheimer's disease. Clin Ther. 2004 Jul;26(7):980-90.

Rosler M, Retz W, Retz-Junginger P, Dennler HJ: Effects of two-year treatment with the cholinesterase inhibitor rivastigmine on behavioural symptoms in Alzheimer's disease. Behav Neurol. 1998;11(4):211-216.

Emre M, Aarsland D, Albanese A, Byrne EJ, Deuschl G, De Deyn PP, Durif F, Kulisevsky J, van Laar T, Lees A, Poewe W, Robillard A, Rosa MM, Wolters E, Quarg P, Tekin S, Lane R: Rivastigmine for dementia associated with Parkinson's disease. N Engl J Med. 2004 Dec 9;351(24):2509-18.
Birks J, Grimley Evans J, Iakovidou V, Tsolaki M, Holt FE: Rivastigmine for Alzheimer's disease. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2009 Apr 15;(2):CD001191. doi: 10.1002/14651858.CD001191.pub2.

Naik RS, Hartmann J, Kiewert C, Duysen EG, Lockridge O, Klein J: Effects of rivastigmine and donepezil on brain acetylcholine levels in acetylcholinesterase-deficient mice. J Pharm Pharm Sci. 2009;12(1):79-85.
Farlow MR: Update on rivastigmine. Neurologist. 2003 Sep;9(5):230-4.

drug.synthesis-reference: Venkata Naga Brahmeswara Rao Mandava, Venkata Reddy Vajrala, Ganesh Varanasi, Vijay Kumar Adla, Mukund Reddy Jambula, Vijaypal Reddy Kanumathi Reddy, "PREPARATION OF RIVASTIGMINE AND ITS SALTS." U.S. Patent US20080255383, issued October 16, 2008.
drug.indication: For the treatment of mild to moderate dementia associated with Parkinson's disease or of the Alzheimer's type.
drug.pharmacodynamics: Rivastigmine is a parasympathomimetic and a reversible cholinesterase inhibitor. An early pathophysiological feature of Alzheimer's disease that is associated with memory loss and cognitive deficits is a deficiency of acetylcholine as a result of selective loss of cholinergic neurons in the cerebral cortex, nucleus basalis, and hippocampus. Tacrine is postulated to exert its therapeutic effect by enhancing cholinergic function. While the precise mechanism of rivastigmine's action is unknown, it is postulated to exert its therapeutic effect by enhancing cholinergic function. This is accomplished by increasing the concentration of acetylcholine through reversible inhibition of its hydrolysis by cholinesterase. If this proposed mechanism is correct, rivastigmine's effect may lessen as the disease progresses and fewer cholinergic neurons remain functionally intact.
drug.mechanism-of-action: Rivastigmine is a carbamate derivative that is structurally related to physostigmine, but not to donepezil and tacrine. The precise mechanism of rivastigmine has not been fully determined, but it is suggested that rivastigmine binds reversibly with and inactivates chlolinesterase (eg. acetylcholinesterase, butyrylcholinesterase), preventing the hydrolysis of acetycholine, and thus leading to an increased concentration of acetylcholine at cholinergic synapses. The anticholinesterase activity of rivastigmine is relatively specific for brain acetylcholinesterase and butyrylcholinesterase compared with those in peripheral tissues.
drug.metabolism: Rivastigmine is rapidly metabolized by cholinesterase-mediated hydrolysis.
drug.route-of-elimination: Rivastigmine is extensively metabolized primarily via cholinesterase-mediated hydrolysis to the decarbamylated metabolite NAP226-90. Renal excretion of the metabolites is the major route of elimination. Less than 1% of the administered dose is excreted in the feces.

classification.description: This compound belongs to the class of organic compounds known as phenoxy compounds. These are aromatic compounds contaning a phenoxy group.

category.category: Compounds used in a research, industrial, or household setting

drug-interaction.description: The therapeutic efficacy of Rivastigmine can be decreased when used in combination with Prednisone acetate.

drug-interaction.name: Clocortolone acetate
drug-interaction.description: The therapeutic efficacy of Rivastigmine can be decreased when used in combination with Clocortolone acetate.

drug-interaction.name: Melengestrol acetate
drug-interaction.description: The therapeutic efficacy of Rivastigmine can be decreased when used in combination with Melengestrol acetate.

drug-interaction.name: Betamethasone phosphate
drug-interaction.description: The therapeutic efficacy of Rivastigmine can be decreased when used in combination with Betamethasone phosphate.

drug-interaction.name: Cortisone
drug-interaction.description: The therapeutic efficacy of Rivastigmine can be decreased when used in combination with Cortisone.

drug-interaction.name: Metocurine iodide
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Metocurine iodide.

drug-interaction.name: Gallamine triethiodide
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Gallamine triethiodide.

drug-interaction.name: Cisatracurium
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Cisatracurium.

drug-interaction.name: Rocuronium
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Rocuronium.

drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Atracurium besylate.

drug-interaction.name: Doxacurium
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Doxacurium.

drug-interaction.name: Tubocurarine
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Tubocurarine.

drug-interaction.name: Mivacurium
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Mivacurium.

drug-interaction.name: Metocurine
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Metocurine.

drug-interaction.name: Pancuronium
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Pancuronium.

drug-interaction.name: Pipecuronium
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Pipecuronium.

drug-interaction.name: Vecuronium
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Vecuronium.

drug-interaction.name: Rapacuronium
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Rapacuronium.

drug-interaction.name: Atracurium
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Atracurium.

drug-interaction.name: Gallamine
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Gallamine.

drug-interaction.name: Alcuronium
drug-interaction.description: Rivastigmine may decrease the neuromuscular blocking activities of Alcuronium.

drug-interaction.name: Amifampridine
drug-interaction.description: The risk or severity of adverse effects can be increased when Rivastigmine is combined with Amifampridine.

drug-interaction.name: Lasmiditan
drug-interaction.description: Lasmiditan may increase the bradycardic activities of Rivastigmine.

polypeptide.name: Acetylcholinesterase
polypeptide.specific-function: Terminates signal transduction at the neuromuscular junction by rapid hydrolysis of the acetylcholine released into the synaptic cleft. Role in neuronal apoptosis.

go-classifier.description: acetylcholine catabolic process in synaptic cleft
negative regulation of synaptic transmission, cholinergic

polypeptide.name: Cholinesterase
polypeptide.specific-function: Esterase with broad substrate specificity. Contributes to the inactivation of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine. Can degrade neurotoxic organophosphate esters.
